title: 107_hr561
content: The "Election Reform Commission Act of 2001" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Election Reform with specified membership. The Commission, established by the "Election Reform Commission Act of 2001," consists of 17 members appointed by various political leaders, with specific allocations for each appointing authority. The Commission, established by the "Election Reform Commission Act of 2001," consists of 17 members appointed by various political leaders. Members are appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment for the life of the Commission. Vacancies do not affect its powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and additional meetings can be called by the Chair or a majority of members. A majority of the Commission constitutes a quorum for business transactions. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with examining issues affecting elections for Federal, State, and local offices in the United States, including the electoral college's impact on voter turnout and alternative methods of allocating electoral votes, as well as voter registration issues such as the effectiveness of the National Voter Registration Act of 1993 and the feasibility of same-day voter registration. Issues related to ballot design, technology, and polling places are being examined by the Commission. This includes discussions on the design of ballots, technology used for processing and counting votes, uniform ballot designs, standards for voting equipment maintenance, and steps to reduce counting errors. Additionally, the timing of polling places is also being considered. Issues related to the timing of elections, quality of services at polling places, ballot access, and alternative methods of casting votes are being examined by the Commission. This includes discussions on establishing a uniform poll closing time, Election Day as a Federal holiday, accessible polling places, worker training, and voter education. Additionally, alternative methods of voting such as voting through the mail or Internet are being considered to ensure effective participation of absent military and overseas voters. Overseas voters can cast votes effectively and timely, with election officials verifying legality. The Commission will submit a final report to Congress and the President within 12 months, including analysis and recommendations. Any member can submit additional findings and recommendations. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 5. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and request administrative support services as needed to fulfill the requirements of the Act. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request, on a reimbursable basis, to help the Commission carry out its duties under this Act. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission will be compensated based on their status as government employees or not, with non-government members receiving a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Government members will serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses, including per diem, will be provided to all members at authorized rates. The Chair of the Commission has the authority to appoint and terminate staff, request the detail of Federal employees, and accept temporary services. The employment of an executive director is subject to the approval of the Commission. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its final report. Sums necessary for the Commission's operations are authorized to be appropriated.
